Graphical abstract A series of doped barium cerate perovskite catalysts (BaCeO3-δ, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ) were prepared by a two-step process consisting of solid-state synthesis followed by high-energy ball milling. X-ray diffraction studies showed that the dopants (Zr and Co) were incorporated into the perovskite lattice. TPR studies revealed that the high-energy ball milling process significantly enhanced the reducibility of the catalysts. XPS data indicated a shift in electron density away from the metal centres and an increase in defect oxides, for the high-energy ball milled catalysts, which led to enhanced activity of the catalysts. The catalytic performance was evaluated in a fixed bed reactor system under simulated diesel exhaust conditions, including water. The high-energy ball milled barium cerate sample co-doped with Zr and Co exhibited NOx storage of ∼228 μmol/g at 380 °C and a Tmax, at which the rate of soot oxidation reaction was maximum, of 436 °C. Keywords Barium cerate NOx storage Soot oxidation High-energy ball milling 1 Introduction Diesel engines are highly efficient, durable and have relatively low operating cost. They are the preferred engine for heavy-duty transport vehicles. The main pollutants emitted by diesel engines are nitrous oxides (NOx) and particulate matter (PM), which have adverse environmental impact and are deleterious to human health [1,2]. Diesel particulate filters (DPF) are used to eliminate particulate matter from diesel exhaust [1]. Elimination of NOx under the lean operating conditions of diesel engines is difficult. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR), using either urea, hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide or hydrogen as a reductant, is one method used to convert NOx to N2. NOx storage and reduction (NSR), also referred to as lean NOx trap (LNT), is an alternative to SCR technology [1]. State-of-the art LNTs employ Pt, which reduces NOx to N2 under rich (low oxygen concentration) operating conditions, in combination with barium compounds, which store the NOx during lean operating cycles [1]. The use of precious metals makes these LNTs relatively expensive. In addition, Pt is susceptible to sulfur poisoning [1,2]. Perovskite and perovskite-like materials, chemical formula ABO3 and A2BO4, respectively, are low cost, thermally and hydrothermally stable alternative LNT materials with good catalytic performance [3,4]. Substitution of the cation ion (B) creates oxygen vacancies (ABO3-δ) within the perovskite structure that can alter the catalytic properties. The type of ions substituted into the cation B sites in the perovskite structure are restricted by the Goldschmidt tolerance factor (t) such that 0.75 < t < 1.0, where (1) t = r A + r O 2 r B + r O rA, rB, and rO are the respective ion radii, ABO3 [3]. Lanthanum-based perovskites for the simultaneous elimination of NOx and PM from diesel exhaust have been extensively studied [5–30]. Lanthanum based perovskites have been shown to decompose NO to N2, however, their activity decreased when large amounts of oxygen was present [31]. Barium-based perovskites have, however, received considerably less attention for use as LNTs and for soot oxidation [32–40]. Barium is routinely used as the NOx storage component in precious metal based LNTs [1]. Palladium doped barium cerate perovskites were shown to be excellent CO oxidation catalysts [36,37]. Recently, precious metal-doped barium cerate was shown to be effective for simultaneous conversion of NOx, CO and propylene in lean burn engines [33]. In this paper, simultaneous NOx storage and soot oxidation performance of doped barium cerate perovskite materials are reported. The catalysts were prepared by a two-step process consisting of solid-state synthesis (SSS) followed by high-energy ball milling (HEBM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to study the effect of metal dopants on crystal structure. The surface area was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The catalytic performance for simultaneous NOx storage and soot oxidation was evaluated in a fixed bed reactor system, under simulated diesel exhaust conditions, including water. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) in hydrogen was used to study the reducibility of the metals in the catalysts. Surface analysis of the catalysts was done by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation BaCeO3-δ, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ perovskite catalysts were prepared by SSS using high purity oxide and carbonate precursors (>99.9%). Appropriate amounts of precursor powders were mixed (Turbula Type T2 F shaker mixer) for approximately 0.5 h. Batch sizes were approximately 15 g. After mixing, the powders were calcined at 1000 °C for 2 h. The powders were crushed in an agate mortar with a pestle and then fired at 1350 °C for 10 h [40–43]. The powders were subjected to a post firing treatment in a HEBM for 24 h (Planetary Ball Mill QM-3SP04). The ball to powder ratio was approximately 10:1. The balls and jar (100 mL) were made of yttria-stabilized zirconia. The ball mill frequency was 600 rotations min−1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area was measured by the BET N2 adsorption method using a TriStar II 3020 instrument (Micromeritics Inc.). The samples were degassed at 250 °C for 5 h and N2 adsorption was carried out at 77 K. Crystal structures of the barium cerate based catalyst powders were determined by XRD. Diffractograms were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV XRD spectrometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and equipped with a diffracted-beam monochromator and a high-speed semiconductor one-dimensional x-ray detector (D/teX Ultra). XRD patterns were collected over the 2θ angular range of 20–90° at a scanning rate of 1° min−1 and 0.01° intervals. Diffraction peaks of crystalline phases were identified using the International Center for Diffraction Data (ICDD) database. The average crystallite size was calculated based on the Scherrer equation using the Rigaku PDXL Diffraction software’s whole pattern profile fitting program. A Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 Analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector was used for H2-TPR studies. The catalyst was pretreated in He flow of 30 mL min−1 at 400 °C for 30 min. The sample was then cooled to room temperature in the same He flow. The H2-TPR profile was obtained when the catalyst was heated to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in a 50 mL min−1 flow of 10 vol% H2 balance argon gas mixture. The chemical surface properties of the samples (∼3-7 nm) were analyzed by XPS using a Kratos Axis Ultra XPS equipped with a monochromated Al X-ray source. Three analyses were performed on each sample. Analyses were carried out using an accelerating voltage of 14 kV and a current of 10 mA. The analysis area is 300 x 700 μm. Charge build-up was compensated for using the Axis charge balancing system. Analyses consisted first of a survey scan performed at a pass energy of 160 eV to identify all the species present, followed by high-resolution scans (20 eV) of the species identified by the survey scan. Peak assignments were based on the NIST database (http://srdata.nist.gov/xps/Bind_E.asp) and relevant publications. Peak fitting was performed using CasaXPS (ver. 23.16dev92) data processing software. Shirley background correction procedures were used as provided by CasaXPS. High-resolution analyses were calibrated to the C 1s signal, at 284.8 eV. Quantification was performed using sensitivity factors provided by CasaXPS’s Scofield element library. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests Catalysts were tested under simulated diesel exhaust conditions using a fixed bed reactor system. Carbon, (Monarch 120 from Cabot) as a model soot compound, was added to the catalyst in a weight ratio of 1:30 carbon:catalyst. The carbon and catalyst were mixed with a mortar and pestle to obtain a tight contact that was easy to reproduce and allowed for performance screening studies based on the intrinsic catalyst activity. To prevent excessive backpressure all catalyst-carbon mixtures were pelletized and sieved to a particle size in the range of 125–180 μm prior to testing. The test sample of 500 mg (±10 mg) was loaded in a 6 mm quartz reactor tube between two pieces of quartz wool. Samples were pretreated as follows: under a nitrogen flow of 500 mL min−1 the temperature was ramped from 75 to 400 °C at a rate of 3 °C min−1, the sample was held at 400 °C for 0.5 h and then allowed to cool to 75 °C. The process gas composition used for catalytic activity tests was 10 vol. % O2, 5 vol. % H2O, 500 ppm NO balance nitrogen, the reaction gas flow rate was 500 mL min−1. The temperature was ramped from 75 to 600 °C at a rate of 3 °C min−1. The effluent gas was analyzed using an MKS Multi Gas 2030 FTIR analyzer. The change in NOx concentration in the outlet was plotted against temperature and the relative change of NOx concentration (ΔNOx) was calculated as follows: (2) ΔNOx (%) = [(NOx-in-NOx-out)/NOx-in] x100 where NOx=NO + NO2. The NOx storage capacity was determined under isothermal conditions by consecutive NOx storage-reduction cycles. The storage capacity was calculated by integrating the area under the curve during the NOx storage cycle, see Fig. S1. The samples were pretreated at 400 °C for 0.5 h under a nitrogen flow of 500 mL min−1. During the storage cycle (10 min) the gas composition was 500 ppm NO, 10 vol. % O2, 5 vol. % H2O balance nitrogen. For the reduction cycle (10 min) the gas composition was 10 vol. % H2, 5 vol. % H2O balance nitrogen. The gas flow for both cycles was 500 mL min−1. The effluent gas was analyzed using an MKS Multi Gas 2030 FTIR analyzer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD characterization The XRD patterns for the BaCeO3-δ, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ catalysts prepared by SSS are shown in Fig. 1 A and those prepared by SSS + HEBM are shown in Fig. 1B. All the catalysts processed by SSS had orthorhombic perovskite structure similar to that reported for platinum group metal doped barium cerate [33], the lattice parameters are given in Table 1 . However, the catalyst samples prepared by SSS + HEBM had cubic perovskite structure, the lattice parameters are given in Table 1. The change in crystal structure for the SSS + HEBM processed samples can be ascribed to the HEBM step and are a consequence of the transfer of kinetic energy from the milling media to the catalyst samples during high energy impacts that occurred during the HEBM process. Some minor impurity peaks (marked with an asterisks in Fig. 1B) were detected, see Table 1. The same impurity phases were detected in the SSS and SSS + HEBM catalyst samples but are not as apparent in the SSS samples due to the larger peak intensities. The impurity phase detected in the BaCeO3-δ catalysts was assigned to BaCO3, the impurity phase detected in the BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ samples was a combination of BaZrO3 and ZrO2 and the impurity phase in the BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ samples was assigned to BaCoO3. The appearance of the impurity phases are due to the fact that decomposition of barium carbonate is difficult [41–43] and the refractory nature of zirconia. The samples prepared by SSS had much sharper diffraction peaks, indicative of large crystallite size, and can be ascribed to the high temperature processing step. The peak intensities for the Zr and Co-doped barium cerate sample (c in Fig. 1A) are weaker due to the small sample size used. In addition, the peak widths for this catalyst are broader than for the other two (Fig. 1A) indicating this sample has smaller crystallite size (see Table 1). The peak widths for the catalysts prepared by SSS + HEBM are broader, Fig. 1B, indicating smaller crystallite size. The crystallite sizes determined from XRD data, using the Scherrer formula, are given in Table 1. The crystallite size for the various BaCeO3-δ based catalysts prepared by SSS only were much larger than those prepared by SSS + HEBM, as expected. The significant decrease in crystallite size indicated that HEBM was beneficial, at least in terms of crystallite size reduction. 3.2 XPS characterization The survey spectra for the BaCeO3-δ samples (not shown) were used to determine the chemical composition for the SSS and SSS + HEBM samples as Ba0.98Ce1.01O2.16 and Ba0.98Ce1.00O2.02, respectively. The Ba high-resolution spectra are shown in Fig. 2 a and d, respectively. Comparison of both images shows a change in the ratios of the three main Ba 3d peaks, labelled a, b and c, Table S1. Each spectra exhibits typical splitting of the d-orbitals with a, b and c representing the 3d5/2 peak and a’, b’, c’ denoting the corresponding 3d3/2 peak [44,45]. In the BaCeO3-δ SSS sample, the strongest of the three peaks is the a and a’ pair while for the SSS + HEBM sample the peak pair of b and b’ are the strongest. This shift in Ba states to higher binding energy indicates a decrease in the electron density around the Ba sites. The Ce high-resolution peaks show the same trends, as indicated in Fig. 2b and e. In the case of the Ce spectra, both the SSS (Fig. 2b) and SSS + HEBM (Fig. 2e) show multiple splitting of the peaks, Table S2, as a result of f-orbital availability [46]. This creates several apparently broad peak shapes, with small deviations and distinctions in each spectrum [46,47]. A similar pattern is noted to that reported in the Ba spectra, wherein the low binding energy peaks decrease and the high binding energy peaks increase. These spectra again confirm a decrease in electron density about the metal centre Ce, again indicating an increased presence of defect oxides associated with Ce. The complex nature of rare earth metal presence leads to a very broad oxygen peak [48] and the corresponding decrease in binding energy associated with the increased electron density around the oxygen, Fig. 2c and f. Both spectra contain a broad oxygen signal, with several very low binding energy peaks [49]. Neither the Ce or Ba spectra give any indication of excessive peak broadening, so the broadness of the oxygen peak has to be ascribed to some physical property inherent to only the oxygen. To do this without adding an excessive number of oxygen species, each of the expected peaks was doubled – one for the surface and one for the ‘bulk’ – with about 2 eV separation. The separation was intrinsically determined. This allows for fits that match the logical sense of the sample and maintain consistency within the XPS data. The lattice oxides [50] account for 23.08% of the signal in the SSS (Fig. 2c) sample and for 28.02% of the signal in the SSS + HEBM (Fig. 2f) sample, Table S3. Defect oxides and hydroxides [50], account for significantly more in both samples, with 42.13%, and 66.22% of the signal, respectively. This behavior indicates a decreased association between O and the f-orbitals of Ce [46,49], as denoted by the loss of some of the distinct low binding energy peaks seen in Fig. 2c. The sample compositions for the Zr-doped barium cerate samples were determined (from the survey spectra, not shown) to be Ba1.00Ce0.95Zr0.10O3.16 for the SSS sample and Ba1.00Ce0.84Zr0.10O1.90 for the SSS + HEBM sample. The oxygen appears under-represented and suggests potential oxygen loss at the surface. The amount of Ce is significantly greater in the SSS sample. The physical process of HEBM has a greater impact on the Ce centres in the Zr-doped samples than in the non-doped samples, allowing some of the Ce to be lost along with the O lost during this process. Whether this loss is as a weakly bound cerium oxide surface region, or a weakening association between cerium and the surrounding lattice remains unclear, but it is clear that the dopants appear to be more closely associated with the barium centre in the lattice. The Ba high-resolution scans of the BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ samples, shown in Fig. 3 a and d, show similar features to those seen in the BaCeO3-δ samples (Fig. 2a and d). As with the previous sample set, a decrease in the a and a’ peak pair and increase in the b and b’ peak pair can be seen in the SSS + HEBM sample (Fig. 3d) as compared to the SSS sample (Fig. 3a). There is also a general decrease in the a and a’ peak pair in both BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ samples (Fig. 3a and d) when compared against the corresponding peaks in the BaCeO3-δ samples from Fig. 2a and d. The peak positioning of this pair also moves to a higher binding energy. Another difference between the two sample sets is the appearance of the peak at position g. This peak is quite a bit lower than is normal for barium spectra and is associated with additional f-orbital overlap with some of the barium centres [48]. This suggests that some of the drastic difference in oxygen noted in the survey spectra is surface-state related [50]. The Ce spectra of the Zr-doped samples (Fig. 3b and e) show more of the same trend, both with respect to the SSS vs SSS + HEBM sample, and with respect to the Zr-doped vs non-doped sample set. The addition of the HEBM step reduces the low-binding energy peak at position s and position t, and enhances the peak seen at position v. This is in agreement with that seen in the non-doped samples (Fig. 2b and e) and is consistent with increased defect oxide formation, or lattice disruptions [46,50]. Compared to the non-doped samples, the Zr-doped samples have reduced low-binding energy character, as noted by the lower peak contribution at position s in Fig. 3b, as compared to that in Fig. 2b. There is a significantly more visible Ba MNN auger line at position u in the SSS + HEBM sample (Fig. 3e) and the Zr-doped samples appear to have a greater peak u than the non-doped samples, Fig. 2e. The O 1s spectra shown in Fig. 3c and f show the same trends as the non-doped samples, Fig. 2c and f. In this case, the defect oxide is significantly more prevalent in the SSS + HEBM sample (Fig. 3f) than in the SSS sample (Fig. 3c) and there is a distinct secondary oxide in the SSS sample that isn’t present in the SSS + HEBM sample. These features resemble those noted in the non-doped samples and gives strong support to the assertions that the HEBM process creates additional defect sites, as noted through increased electron density around the oxygen. Compared to the non-doped samples (Fig. 2c and f), the Zr-doped samples show additional defect oxide character, but with different association between the oxygen orbitals and the Ce f-orbitals. This is evident by the decrease in distinct peaks in the low binding energy region [46,48]. The presence of the Zr-dopant was observed in the XPS spectra (not shown), however, due to the extreme overlap between the Zr 3d, the Ba 4p and the Ce 4p peaks, no meaningful data could be extracted from these spectra. The composition of the Zr- and Co-doped barium cerate samples was determined (from the survey spectra, not shown) to be Ba1.00 Ce0.93Zr0.09Co0.09O2.65 for the SSS sample and Ba1.00Ce0.78Zr0.11Co0.09O2.02 for the SSS + HEBM sample. As with the Zr-doped samples, these samples also show significant oxygen loss compared to the expected atomic ratios. The high-resolution scans show the same trends seen in both the non-doped and the Zr-doped samples, with increased electron density on the oxygen and decreased density on the metals. The Ba high-resolution scans (Fig. 4 a and d) show a further shift in the peak pair at position a and a’, with an increase in both the b and b’ pair, and the c and c’ pair, relative to the other dopant levels, and after HEBM. The Ce 3d high-resolution spectra (Fig. 4b and e) show a significant increase in the prominence of the peak at position v in the SSS + HEBM sample (Fig. 4e) relative to the SSS sample (Fig. 4b). The peak in position t decreases significantly in Fig. 4e, which is again consistent with the proposed decreased electron density on the metal centres. The peak at position s is present in the SSS + HEBM sample (Fig. 4e) but not in the SSS sample (Fig. 4b). This suggests that the Co-dopant must therefore be returning some electron density to the Ce [46]. In the oxygen spectra (Fig. 4c and f), the addition of the cobalt dopant removes the second lattice oxide observed in the previous samples. The XPS data clearly show that the HEBM process increases the electron density around the oxygen centres in the SSS + HEBM samples and decreases the electron density around the metal centres. This behaviour is a result of increased defect oxide formation within the structure, with evidence of a potential separate surface structure difference due to the low oxygen percentages observed in most of the samples. The introduction of dopants (Co and Zr) also increased the electron density around the oxygen centre and decreased it around the metal centres. The Co-dopant was less effective at creating this electron density shift, as compared to the Zr-dopant, and resulted in the Zr- and Co-doped BaCeO3-δ sample yielding less defect oxides than the Zr-doped sample, but still significantly more than the non-doped sample. 3.3 H2-TPR TPR can provide information on the reduction behaviour of catalysts. Fig. 5 a shows the TPR profile for commercial Co3O4 powder (particle size < 50 nm) used as a precursor for the solid-state synthesis of the cobalt doped barium cerate samples. The profile shows a wide asymmetric reduction peak from approximately 300–500 °C. Previous studies [51–54] have shown that reduction of Co3O4 proceeds by a two step process as evidenced by two reduction peaks. The first reduction step is ascribed to reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the second reduction step, usually occurring at higher temperature, to reduction of CoO to Co. The data in Fig. 5a suggest that both reduction processes are occurring within the temperature range of ∼300–500 °C. For small crystallite sizes, as for the current sample (particle size < 50 nm), the two stage reduction process can combine into one peak [53]. The hydrogen consumption was determined by integration of the area beneath the whole profile and the data are tabulated in Table 2 . The H2-TPR profile for commercial CeO2 powders is given in Fig. 5b and c. The same data was used but because the scales are different the CeO2 profile in Fig. 5c appears compressed relative to the profile in Fig. 5b. The profile indicates two reduction peaks at ∼500 and 800 °C. The two reduction regions are characteristic of ceria and are ascribed to surface and bulk reduction processes [55,56]. ZrO2 did not show any H2 consumption over the temperature range studied. ZrO2 only has one oxidation state, 4+, and is therefore a non-reducible oxide. The TPR profiles for BaCeO3-δ, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δprepared by SSS are shown in Fig. 5b. The BaCeO3-δ sample showed one small reduction peak at ∼700-800 °C which can be ascribed to the bulk reduction of ceria, although the peak is shifted to slightly lower temperature than the peak for pure CeO2. The addition of zirconia into ceria affects the redox properties of ceria [56–58] and as shown in Fig. 5b this is manifest by a shift in the reduction peak to slightly lower temperatures (∼700-750 °C). Again, only one reduction peak is observed with a lower hydrogen consumption than for the BaCeO3-δ sample (Table 2). The absence of the first Ce reduction peak can be ascribed to the high processing temperatures (1350 °C for 10 h). This same behaviour was also observed for Zr-doped CeO2 powders subjected to high temperature treatment and was attributed to sintering of ceria [59]. The TPR profile for the BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ sample shows a broad reduction peak from ∼200-700 °C, the peak has two shoulders, one at ∼350 °C and another at ∼700 °C. The shoulder at low temperature can be ascribed to the reduction of Co3O4 and the shoulder at high temperature to the bulk reduction process for Ce4+. The large reduction peak from ∼400-600 °C seems to be due to reduction of Co in combination with the surface reduction process of Ce4+. The hydrogen consumption for this sample is significantly greater (Table 2) than the other two barium cerate samples even though all the samples were subjected to the same high temperature processing (1350 °C/10 h). The TPR profiles for BaCeO3-δ, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ prepared by SSS + HEBM are shown in Fig. 5c. The profiles are dramatically different than those for the samples processed by SSS alone. These data clearly show that the HEBM step affected the redox properties of the catalysts even though the surface areas were quite low (less than 1.5 m2/g for all the catalysts). Additionally, the XPS data showed the HEBM process induced a shift in electron density from the metal centres to the oxide centres resulting from an increased defect oxide formation within the structure which effect the catalytic behaviour. The profile for the BaCeO3-δ sample shows three peaks. The low temperature peak (∼400-600 °C) can be ascribed to the surface reduction process for Ce4+, although the peak is shifted to slightly higher temperatures than for the commercial CeO2 sample. The two high temperature peaks coincide with the high temperature bulk reduction peak for CeO2 but the process consisted of two peaks one occurring at slightly lower and one at higher temperatures than the peak for CeO2. The HEBM process, based on the data in Fig. 5, had a significant impact on the reducibility of the catalyst as evidenced by the significant increase in H2 consumption (∼20 times more, Table 2). The H2-TPR profile for BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ sample is similar to the profile for BaCeO3-δ except that the peaks in the profile are shifted to slightly lower temperature. Additionally, the lower temperature peaks for the BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ catalyst are not as well defined as for the BaCeO3-δ sample. The hydrogen consumption of the BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ sample is ∼20 times more than the sample subjected to SSS (Table 2). The hydrogen consumption of the BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ sample is less than the BaCeO3-δ and this can be ascribed to the lower cerium content of the sample. The H2-TPR profile for the BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ has an additional peak at ∼250-450 °C as compared to the BaCeO3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ samples, this peak can be ascribed to the reduction of Co. The hydrogen consumption is only ∼2 times more than the sample subjected to SSS but that sample already had a significant hydrogen consumption compared to the other two compositions. The H2-TPR data show that HEBM had a significant impact on the reducibility of the catalysts even though the surface area of the samples was quite low. 3.4 Catalyst activity: NOx storage and soot oxidation Fig. 6 a shows the NOx concentration in the outlet gas as a function of temperature for the samples prepared by SSS. Fig. 6b shows the data for the samples processed by SSS and HEBM. The NOx concentration included NO and NO2 concentration while no evolution of N2O was observed. These profiles provide information about changes in NOx concentration due to NO oxidation, NOx adsorption/desorption processes and soot oxidation occurring on the catalyst. For low temperatures (< ∼450 °C) there was no change in NOx concentration for the BaCeO3-δ (SSS) and BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ (SSS) samples. The BaCeO3-δ (SSS + HEBM) and BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ(SSS + HEBM) samples did show changes in NOx concentration (Fig. 6b). The decrease in NOx was due to adsorption while the increase in NOx concentration was due to desorption. The BaCeO3-δ (SSS) sample exhibited a large decrease in the relative change of NOx concentration (ΔNOx) of ∼13% at 520 °C (Fig. 6a). The ΔNOx almost doubled to ∼25% for the sample subjected to a post-processing HEBM treatment (Fig. 6b). Literature data suggest that the redox properties and thermal stability of ceria are enhanced by zirconia [56–58]. Introduction of zirconium into the barium cerate perovskite lattice, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ (Fig. 6a), did not, however, appear to have any beneficial effect at least in terms of the change in NOx concentration. When the BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ sample was subjected to HEBM the NOx peak at ∼500 °C was shifted to lower temperature by ∼10 °C, Fig. 6b. The increase in NOx concentration in the outlet gas for temperatures >∼520 °C was due to desorption from the catalyst surface. NOx concentration in the outlet gas versus temperature for BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ (SSS) and (SSS + HEBM) catalysts is also shown in Fig. 6a and b, respectively. The data revealed a complex behaviour for the catalysts. Clearly, the HEBM process significantly changed the adsorption/desorption behaviour of the catalyst. In the low temperature regime (< ∼450 °C) the (SSS) sample exhibited only relatively weak adsorption and desorption peaks while the SSS + HEBM sample showed relatively large peaks corresponding to both decreases and increases in NOx concentration (due to adsorption/desorption). The co-doped Zr and Co catalyst subjected to a HEBM treatment showed a large decrease in NOx concentration for temperatures in the range of ∼420-500 °C (Fig. 6b). This catalyst had the highest ΔNOx of ∼49% at the lowest temperature (∼455 °C). The percent change in NOx concentration for the BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ perovskite catalysts is comparable to those reported in the literature, typical values range from 20 to 40% [13,14,17,32,34,35]. Beyond ∼500 °C the SSS and SSS + HEBM catalysts exhibited an increase in NOx concentration due to desorption of the adsorbed NOx species. These data show that the cation in the perovskite lattice influences the NOx adsorption/desorption properties of the catalysts to a certain extent but that the HEBM processing step significantly enhanced the adsorption/desorption behaviour. The CO2 concentration in the outlet gas stream due to soot oxidation versus temperature for the various catalysts is shown in Fig. 7 . The figure shows that all the catalysts were active for soot oxidation with Tmax, corresponding to the maximal rate of reaction for soot oxidation, in the range of 480–490 °C. The BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ (SSS) was the worst performing catalyst, in terms of soot oxidation, with a Tmax of ∼530. Tmax values for other barium perovskite catalysts such as Cu-doped barium titanate [34] and Cu-doped barium manganite [32] were also in excess of 500 °C. The presence of zirconium in the lattice enhanced the redox properties [56–58] and had a beneficial effect in terms of soot oxidation as evidenced by the decrease in Tmax for the samples subjected to HEBM. The best performing catalyst for soot oxidation, in terms of Tmax, were the co-doped Zr and Co BaCeO3-δ samples, which exhibited the lowest Tmax value of ∼436 °C. The HEBM processing did not affect the soot oxidation behaviour for the co-doped Zr and Co samples suggesting that the presence of the Co cation in the perovskite lattice was responsible for the enhanced soot oxidation performance. For reference, the CO2 concentration in the outlet gas stream due to soot oxidation versus temperature for a commercial CeO2 sample is also shown in Fig. 7, the Tmax for this sample was ∼400 °C. The NO2/NOx ratio in the outlet gas versus temperature for the various perovskite catalysts is shown in Fig. 8 . The NO2 concentration in the feed gas was almost nil, within experimental error. All the catalysts were able to oxidize NO to NO2 until approximately 500 °C, beyond that temperature the NO2 percentage decreased due to thermodynamic limitations (dashed line). The BaCeO3-δ sample exhibited a very slight decrease in NO2 concentration for the sample subjected to HEBM. The BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ sample, however, showed a significant increase in NO2 concentration for the HEBM processed sample. This behavior impacted the soot oxidation of these catalysts as shown in Fig. 7. The NO2 concentration profiles for the co-doped Zr and Co samples are similar but the HEBM sample was able to generate slightly more NO2 at lower temperatures compared to the SSS catalyst. The soot oxidation behavior of these two catalysts were very similar (Fig. 7). These data clearly show that the co-doped Zr and Co catalysts generated the most NO2 and were able to generate NO2 at lower temperatures than the other catalysts which, in part, would account for these catalysts being the best performing in terms of soot oxidation. The NOx concentration in the outlet gas versus temperature for the Co-doped sample with and without soot is shown in Fig. 9 . When the activity test was performed without soot, all changes in NOx concentration were due to adsorption/desorption phenomenon and oxidation of NO to NO2. The NOx concentration profile for the Co-doped sample tested in the presence of soot is very different from the NOx profile obtained without soot unlike López-Suárez et al. who found no difference in NOx conversion obtained with or without the presence of soot for a Cu-doped perovskite catalyst [60]. In our study, when soot was present in the sample, the first NOx uptake of the perovskite catalyst was due to NOx adsorption on the catalyst and its starting temperature coincided to the adsorption without soot. However, when the temperature reached ∼350 °C the NOx concentration started to increase without reaching the maximal adsorption and this increase continued until ∼430 °C. At ∼350 °C, the beginning of soot ignition was observed (Fig. 9, green curve) and NO2 appeared in the gas phase (Fig. 8). Oxidation of soot by NOx intermediates led to the increase of NOx concentration in the outlet gas. When the temperature reached ∼430 °C a second decrease of NOx concentration was observed. This decrease could not be explained by adsorption because according to the run without soot NOx desorption occurred at a temperature close to 450 °C. Thus, the observed changes in NOx concentration might be associated with soot oxidation. If soot reduced NO2 only to NO, NOx concentration would be unchanged. Instead, a second peak in NOx concentration below 500 ppm appeared. This peak might be explained by formation of some products not registered as NOx. Furthermore, it should be noticed that at the same temperature when soot was totally oxidized (∼480 °C) NOx concentrations began to increase reflecting a simple NOx intermediate desorption. NOx storage ability of the BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ catalyst subjected to HEBM was investigated at ∼380 °C, Fig. S1 (the temperature at which maximum NOx adsorption was observed, see Fig. 6). The NOx storage capacity under isothermal conditions, and in the presence of water, was approximately 228 μmol/g, comparable to some Pt/Ba/Al2O3 precious metal based LNTs that have storage capacity in the range of 180-500 μmol/g [61–63]. 4 Conclusions Barium cerate based perovskite catalysts were prepared by a two-step process involving solid-state synthesis followed by high-energy ball milling. The conditioning of the samples by high-energy ball milling resulted in a dramatic reduction in crystallite size (∼75%). The addition of metal ion (Zr and Co) on catalytic performance was studied. The co-doped (Zr and Co) barium cerate sample exhibited the largest change in NOx concentration, measured in the outlet gas (∼49%) and the lowest Tmax for soot oxidation (∼436 °C). H-TPR studies revealed that high-energy ball milling significantly enhanced the reducibility of the catalysts. XPS data showed that the high-energy ball milling process increased the electron density around the oxygen centres, regardless of dopant presence, and decreased the electron density around the metal centres. XPS also revealed an increase in defect oxides relative to lattice oxides in the high-energy ball milled samples. The shift in electron density and increase in defect oxides enhanced the activity of the catalyst even though the surface areas were rather low. The NOx storage capacity of the co-doped (Zr and Co) barium cerate was ∼228 μmol/g at 380 °C, comparable to Pt-based lean NOx traps. These materials offer a low cost alternative to lean NOx traps based on platinum group metals. CRediT authorship contribution statement N. coredata.dc:description: A series of doped barium cerate perovskite catalysts (BaCeO3-δ, BaCe0.8Zr0.2O3-δ and BaCe0.8Zr0.1Co0.1O3-δ) were prepared by a two-step process consisting of solid-state synthesis followed by high-energy ball milling. X-ray diffraction studies showed that the dopants (Zr and Co) were incorporated into the perovskite lattice. TPR studies revealed that the high-energy ball milling process significantly enhanced the reducibility of the catalysts. XPS data indicated a shift in electron density away from the metal centres and an increase in defect oxides, for the high-energy ball milled catalysts, which led to enhanced activity of the catalysts. The catalytic performance was evaluated in a fixed bed reactor system under simulated diesel exhaust conditions, including water. The high-energy ball milled barium cerate sample co-doped with Zr and Co exhibited NOx storage of ∼228 μmol/g at 380 °C and a Tmax, at which the rate of soot oxidation reaction was maximum, of 436 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Doped barium cerate perovskite catalysts for simultaneous NOx storage and soot oxidation
